intro: Cracca collina, commonly known as the hill cracca, is a flowering plant native to the Mediterranean region. It is a member of the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its slender, branched stems and small, white or pale yellow flowers. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky soils and thrives in full sun. Its leaves are finely divided and aromatic, often used in traditional herbal remedies. Cracca collina is also valued for its ornamental appeal in gardens due to its delicate appearance.
